Description: Brass lamp; flat-topped, elongated, rounded body tapering to a flaring nozzle-end, with a circular dished area round the circular wick-hole. Raised rim round the filling-hole, with hinge-pieces at the rear holding a circular lamp-lid with a simplified baluster knob. At the rear is a double rod-handle of square section, rising from hooked springs, joining, separating and joining again in an elaborate stylised floral form, bound at the joins and with leaves and buds; on the upper bud stands a bird. The lamp stands on a high flaring base, hollow within, and with a square-sectioned socket for the spike of a lampstand. This socket, the sleeve of which is cylindrical, rises inside the oil-chamber almost to the top of the lamp. Surface colouration: dark green.
Curator's comments: Near: Sotheby New York 'Sale Catalogue' 24-5 November 1987, Lot 490; Eton College, Myers Collection, No. 1168, from Egypt.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (3820)
Budge 1922 / British Museum. Guide to the fourth, fifth and sixth Egyptian rooms, and the Coptic room (p.318,41)
Xanthopoulou 2010 / Les lampes en bronze à l’époque paléochrétienne (LA 3.214)
